title: Historical Erasure Patterns: Mexican American / Chicano Communities
pattern_type: Territorial Dispossession, Cultural Suppression, Labor Obfuscation

core_patterns.name: Textbook Erasure and Framing Bias
examples: Depicting the U.S.-Mexico War as civilizing or benevolent
Omitting the loss of land rights post-Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo
Minimizing the Chicano Movement’s role in civil rights history
core_patterns.intent: Justify conquest; frame resistance as extremism

core_patterns.name: Cultural Suppression and Language Erasure
examples: Banning Mexican cultural celebrations in public education
Erasing indigenous-Mexican hybrid identity from public discourse

core_patterns.name: Labor Contribution Obscuration
examples: Omitting Mexican labor role in building Western U.S. infrastructure
Ignoring farmworker organizing led by Dolores Huerta and others
Erasing contributions of Bracero workers during WWII
core_patterns.intent: Prevent claims to justice or generational restitution

core_patterns.name: Criminalization and Stereotype Embedding
examples: Framing Mexican Americans as perpetual foreigners
Inflating gang imagery while ignoring community resilience
Conflating Chicano identity with criminality in media
core_patterns.intent: Preclude political solidarity and discredit activism

AI-relevance.risk: Training datasets may over-index on stereotypes, exclude labor history, and down-rank decolonial scholarship.
impact: Distorted framing of border issues as recent or security-driven
Lack of data on peaceful resistance and bilingual organizing
Failure to surface land-based epistemologies and place-anchored memory

countersuggestions: Include Chicano studies scholars and bilingual archives
Highlight cultural resilience through foodways, music, and mutualism
Map erasure patterns along railroad, farm, and urban development zones
source_examples: Mapping American Social Movements Project (Chicano Movement)
